  * [Politics of United States](/wiki/Politics_of_United_States "Politics of United States")

In the 1860s, the **Copperheads** were a vocal faction of
[Democrats](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_Democratic_Party "History of
the United States Democratic Party") in the [Northern United
States](/wiki/Northern_United_States "Northern United States") of the
[Union](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\) "Union \(American Civil War\)") who
opposed the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil
War") and wanted an immediate peace settlement with the
[Confederates](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America").

[Republicans](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_Republican_Party "History of
the United States Republican Party") started calling anti-war Democrats
"Copperheads", likening them to the [venomous snake](/wiki/Copperhead_snake
"Copperhead snake"). Those Democrats accepted the label, reinterpreting the
copper "head" as the likeness of Liberty, which they cut from [Liberty Head
large cent](/wiki/Large_cent_\(United_States_coin\)#Braided_Hair "Large cent
\(United States coin\)") coins and proudly wore as badges.[1] By contrast,
Democratic supporters of the war were called [War
Democrats](/wiki/War_Democrats "War Democrats"). The Copperheads represented
the more extreme wing of the Northern Democrats. Notable Copperheads included
two Democratic Congressmen from Ohio: [Clement L.
Vallandigham](/wiki/Clement_Vallandigham "Clement Vallandigham") and
[Alexander Long](/wiki/Alexander_Long "Alexander Long"). Republican
prosecutors accused some prominent Copperheads of treason in a series of
trials in 1864.[2]

Copperheadism was a highly contentious grass-roots movement. It had its
strongest base in the area just north of the Ohio River as well as in some
urban ethnic wards. Some historians have argued that it represented a
traditionalistic element alarmed at the rapid modernization of society
sponsored by the Republican Party and that it looked back to [Jacksonian
democracy](/wiki/Jacksonian_democracy "Jacksonian democracy") for inspiration.
Weber (2006) argues that the Copperheads damaged the Union war effort by
opposing [conscription](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States#Civil_War
"Conscription in the United States") (the "draft"), encouraging
[desertion](/wiki/Desertion#American_Civil_War "Desertion") and forming
conspiracies, but other historians say that the draft was already in disrepute
and that the Republicans greatly exaggerated the conspiracies for partisan
reasons.

Historians such as Wood Gray and Jennifer Weber argue that the Copperheads
were inflexibly rooted in the past and were naive about the refusal of the
Confederates to return to the Union. Convinced that the Republicans were
ruining the traditional world they loved, they were obstructionist
partisans.[3] In turn, the Copperheads became a major target of the [National
Union Party](/wiki/National_Union_Party_\(United_States\) "National Union
Party \(United States\)") in the [1864 presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1864 "United States
presidential election, 1864"), where they were used to discredit the main
Democratic candidates. Copperhead support increased when Union armies did
poorly and decreased when they won great victories. After the [fall of
Atlanta](/wiki/Battle_of_Atlanta "Battle of Atlanta") in September 1864, Union
military success seemed assured and Copperheadism collapsed.

##
Agenda[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copperhead_\(politics\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Agenda")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/~abe2.jpg/220px-~abe2.jpg)](/wiki/File:~abe2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:~abe2.jpg "Enlarge")

Copperhead pamphlet from 1864 by [Charles Chauncey
Burr](/wiki/Charles_Chauncey_Burr "Charles Chauncey Burr"), a magazine editor
from New York City[4]

During the American Civil War (1861–1865), the Copperheads nominally favored
the Union and strongly opposed the war, for which they blamed
[abolitionists](/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism in the
United States") and they demanded immediate peace and resisted [draft
laws](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the United
States"). They wanted President [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln
"Abraham Lincoln") and the Republicans ousted from power, seeing the President
as a tyrant destroying American
[republican](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States "Republicanism in the
United States") values with despotic and arbitrary actions.[5]

Some Copperheads tried to persuade [Union soldiers](/wiki/Union_Army "Union
Army") to desert. They talked of helping Confederate [prisoners of
war](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war") seize their camps and escape.
They sometimes met with Confederate agents and took money. The Confederacy
encouraged their activities whenever possible.[6]

##
Newspapers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copperhead_\(politics\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Newspapers")]

The Copperheads had numerous important newspapers, but the editors never
formed an alliance. In Chicago, [Wilbur F. Storey](/wiki/Wilbur_F._Storey
"Wilbur F. Storey") made the _[Chicago Times](/wiki/Chicago_Times "Chicago
Times")_ into Lincoln's most vituperative enemy.[7] The New York _Journal of
Commerce_ , originally abolitionist, was sold to owners who became
Copperheads, giving them an important voice in the largest city. A typical
editor was Edward G. Roddy, owner of the [Uniontown,
Pennsylvania](/wiki/Uniontown,_Pennsylvania "Uniontown, Pennsylvania") _Genius
of Liberty_. He was an intensely partisan Democrat who saw [African
Americans](/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans") as an inferior race
and Lincoln as a despot and dunce. Although he supported the war effort in
1861, he blamed abolitionists for prolonging the war and denounced the
government as increasingly despotic. By 1864, he was calling for peace at any
price.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

[John Mullaly](/wiki/John_Mullaly "John Mullaly")'s _Metropolitan Record_ was
the official [Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_the_United_States "Roman
Catholicism in the United States") newspaper in New York City. Reflecting
[Irish American](/wiki/Irish_American "Irish American") opinion, it supported
the war until 1863 before becoming a Copperhead organ. In the spring and
summer of 1863, the paper urged its Irish working-class readers to pursue
armed resistance to the draft passed by Congress earlier in the year. When the
draft began in the city, working class [European
Americans](/wiki/European_Americans "European Americans"), largely Irish,
responded with [violent riots](/wiki/New_York_City_draft_riots "New York City
draft riots") from July 13 to 16, lynching, beating and hacking to death more
than 100 black New Yorkers and burning down black-owned businesses and
institutions, including an orphanage for 233 black children. On August 19,
1864, John Mullaly was arrested for inciting resistance to the draft.

Even in an era of extremely partisan journalism, Copperhead newspapers were
remarkable for their angry rhetoric. Wisconsin newspaper editor [Marcus M.
Pomeroy](/wiki/Marcus_M._Pomeroy "Marcus M. Pomeroy") of the _La Crosse
Democrat_ referred to Lincoln as "Fungus from the corrupt womb of bigotry and
fanaticism" and a "worse tyrant and more inhuman butcher than has existed
since the days of [Nero](/wiki/Nero "Nero") [...] The man who votes for
Lincoln now is a traitor and murderer [...] And if he is elected to misgovern
for another four years, we trust some bold hand will pierce his heart with
dagger point for the public good".[8]

## Copperhead
resistance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copperhead_\(politics\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Copperhead resistance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Clement_Vallandigham_-
_Brady-Handy.jpg/170px-Clement_Vallandigham_-_Brady-
Handy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Clement_Vallandigham_-_Brady-Handy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Clement_Vallandigham_-_Brady-Handy.jpg "Enlarge")

[Clement Vallandigham](/wiki/Clement_Vallandigham "Clement Vallandigham"),
leader of the Copperheads, coined the slogan: "To maintain the Constitution as
it is, and to restore the Union as it was"

The Copperheads sometimes talked of violent resistance and in some cases
started to organize. However, they never actually made an organized attack. As
war opponents, Copperheads were suspected of disloyalty and their leaders were
sometimes arrested and held for months in military prisons without trial. One
famous example was General [Ambrose Burnside](/wiki/Ambrose_Burnside "Ambrose
Burnside")'s 1863 [General Order Number 38](/wiki/General_Order_Number_38
"General Order Number 38"), issued in Ohio, which made it an offence (to be
tried in military court) to criticize the war in any way.[9] The order was
used to arrest Ohio congressman [Clement L.
Vallandigham](/wiki/Clement_Vallandigham "Clement Vallandigham") when he
criticized the order itself.[10] However, Lincoln commuted his sentence while
requiring his exile to the Confederacy.

Probably the largest Copperhead group was the [Knights of the Golden
Circle](/wiki/Knights_of_the_Golden_Circle "Knights of the Golden Circle").
Formed in Ohio in the 1850s, it became politicized in 1861. It reorganized as
the Order of American Knights in 1863 and again in early 1864 as the Order of
the Sons of Liberty, with Vallandigham as its commander. One leader, [Harrison
H. Dodd](/wiki/Harrison_H._Dodd "Harrison H. Dodd"), advocated violent
overthrow of the governments of Indiana, Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri in
1864. Democratic Party leaders and a Federal investigation, thwarted his
conspiracy. In spite of this Copperhead setback, tensions remained high. The
[Charleston Riot](/wiki/Charleston_Riot "Charleston Riot") took place in
Illinois in March 1864. Indiana Republicans then used the sensational
revelation of an antiwar Copperhead conspiracy by elements of the Sons of
Liberty to discredit Democrats in the [1864 House
elections](/wiki/United_States_House_election,_1864 "United States House
election, 1864"). The military trial of [Lambdin P.
Milligan](/wiki/Lambdin_P._Milligan "Lambdin P. Milligan") and other Sons of
Liberty revealed plans to set free the Confederate prisoners held in the
state. The culprits were sentenced to hang, but the [Supreme
Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States") intervened in _[ex parte Milligan](/wiki/Ex_parte_Milligan "Ex parte
Milligan")_ , saying they should have received civilian trials.[11]

Most Copperheads actively participated in politics. On May 1, 1863, former
Congressman Vallandigham declared the war was being fought not to save the
Union, but to free the blacks and enslave Southern whites. The army then
arrested him for declaring sympathy for the enemy. He was court-martialed by
the Army and sentenced to imprisonment, but Lincoln [commuted the
sentence](/wiki/Commutation_of_sentence "Commutation of sentence") to
banishment behind Confederate lines.[12] The Democrats nevertheless nominated
him for governor of Ohio in 1863. He campaigned from Canada, but lost after an
intense battle. He operated behind the scenes at the [1864 Democratic
convention](/wiki/1864_Democratic_National_Convention "1864 Democratic
National Convention") in Chicago. This convention adopted a largely Copperhead
platform and selected Ohio Representative [George
Pendleton](/wiki/George_H._Pendleton "George H. Pendleton") (a known Peace
Democrat) as the vice presidential candidate. However, it chose a pro-war
presidential candidate, General [George B.
McClellan](/wiki/George_B._McClellan "George B. McClellan"). The contradiction
severely weakened the party's chances to defeat Lincoln.

##
Characteristics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copperhead_\(politics\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Characteristics")]

The values of the Copperheads reflected the [Jacksonian
democracy](/wiki/Jacksonian_democracy "Jacksonian democracy") of an earlier
agrarian society. The Copperhead movement attracted Southerners who had
settled north of the [Ohio River](/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River"), the poor and
merchants who had lost profitable Southern trade.[13][14] They were most
numerous in border areas, including southern parts of Ohio, Illinois and
Indiana (in Missouri, comparable groups were avowed Confederates).[15]

The movement has scattered bases of support outside the lower Midwest. There
was a Copperhead element in Connecticut that dominated the Democratic Party
there.[16] The Copperhead coalition included many [Irish
American](/wiki/Irish_American "Irish American") Catholics in eastern cities,
mill towns and mining camps (especially in the Pennsylvania coal fields). They
were also numerous in [German](/wiki/German_American "German American")
Catholic areas of the [Midwest](/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern
United States"), especially Wisconsin[17]

Historian [Kenneth Stampp](/wiki/Kenneth_Stampp "Kenneth Stampp") has captured
the Copperhead spirit in his depiction of Congressman [Daniel W.
Voorhees](/wiki/Daniel_W._Voorhees "Daniel W. Voorhees") of Indiana:

> There was an earthy quality in Voorhees, "the tall sycamore of the Wabash."
> On the stump his hot temper, passionate partisanship, and stirring eloquence
> made an irresistible appeal to the western Democracy [i.e. the Democratic
> Party]. His bitter cries against [protective tariffs](/wiki/Protectionism
> "Protectionism") and [national banks](/wiki/National_bank "National bank"),
> his intense [race prejudice](/wiki/Racism "Racism"), his suspicion of the
> eastern [Yankee](/wiki/Yankee "Yankee"), his devotion to personal
> [liberty](/wiki/Liberty "Liberty"), his defense of the
> [Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States
> Constitution") and [State's rights](/wiki/State%27s_rights "State's rights")
> faithfully reflected the views of his constituents. Like other
> [Jacksonian](/wiki/Jacksonian_democracy "Jacksonian democracy")
> [agrarians](/wiki/Agrarianism "Agrarianism"), he resented the political and
> economic revolution then in progress. Voorhees idealized a way of life which
> he thought was being destroyed by the current rulers of his country. His
> bold protests against these dangerous trends made him the idol of the
> [Democracy](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
> \(United States\)") of the [Wabash Valley](/wiki/Wabash_Valley "Wabash
> Valley").[18]

##
Historiography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copperhead_\(politics\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Historiography")]

Two central questions have run through the historiography of the Copperheads,
i.e. "How serious a threat did they pose to the Union war effort and hence to
the nation's survival?" and "to what extent and with what justification did
the Lincoln administration and other Republican officials violate civil
liberties to contain the perceived menace?".[19]

The first book-length scholarly treatment of the Copperheads appeared in 1942.
In _The Hidden Civil War_ , Wood Gray decried the "defeatism" of the
Copperheads. He argued they deliberately served the Confederacy's war aims.
Also in 1942, George Fort Milton published _Abraham Lincoln and the Fifth
Column_ , which likewise condemned the traitorous Copperheads and praised
Lincoln as a model defender of democracy.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[Gilbert R. Tredway](/wiki/Gilbert_R._Tredway "Gilbert R. Tredway"), a
professor of history, in his 1973 study _Democratic Opposition to the Lincoln
Administration in Indiana_ found most Indiana Democrats were loyal to the
Union and desired national reunification. He documented Democratic counties in
Indiana having outperformed Republican counties in the recruitment of
soldiers. Tredway found that Copperhead sentiment was uncommon among the rank-
and-file Democrats in Indiana.[20]

The chief historians who favored the Copperheads are [Richard O.
Curry](/w/index.php?title=Richard_O._Curry&action=edit&redlink=1 "Richard O.
Curry \(page does not exist\)") and [Frank L.
Klement](/w/index.php?title=Frank_L._Klement&action=edit&redlink=1 "Frank L.
Klement \(page does not exist\)"). Klement devoted most of his career to
debunking the idea that the Copperheads represented a danger to the Union.
Klement and Curry have downplayed the treasonable activities of the
Copperheads, arguing the Copperheads were traditionalists who fiercely
resisted modernization and wanted to return to the old ways. Klement argued in
the 1950s that the Copperheads' activities, especially their supposed
participation in treasonous anti-Union secret societies, were mostly false
inventions by Republican propaganda machines designed to discredit the
Democrats at election time. Curry sees Copperheads as poor traditionalists
battling against the railroads, banks and modernization. In his standard
history _[Battle Cry of Freedom](/wiki/Battle_Cry_of_Freedom_\(book\) "Battle
Cry of Freedom \(book\)")_ (1988), [James M.
McPherson](/wiki/James_M._McPherson "James M. McPherson") asserted Klement had
taken "revision a bit too far. There was some real fire under that smokescreen
of Republican propaganda".

Jennifer Weber's _Copperheads_ (2006) agrees more with Gray and Milton than
with Klement. She argues that first. Northern antiwar sentiment was strong, so
strong that Peace Democrats came close to seizing control of their party in
mid-1864. Second, she shows the peace sentiment led to deep divisions and
occasional violence across the North. Third, Weber concluded that the peace
movement deliberately weakened the Union military effort by undermining both
enlistment and the operation of the draft. Indeed, Lincoln had to divert
combat troops to retake control of New York City from the [anti-draft
rioters](/wiki/New_York_City_draft_riots "New York City draft riots") in 1863.
Fourth, Weber shows how the attitudes of Union soldiers affected partisan
battles back home. The soldiers' rejection of Copperheadism and their
overwhelming support for Lincoln's reelection in 1864 was decisive in securing
the Northern victory and the preservation of the Union. The Copperheads'
appeal, she argues, waxed and waned with Union failures and successes in the
field.
